bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench encloses a draft of his manuscript with specific questions for Truby to answer.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 26, 1940
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
After my return from Havana, I was so busy that I could not
set down in orderly fashion, my notes until recently. I have just finished my
memorandum. It is quite confidential, and I am submitting it to you, to General
Kean, Moran, and Senora Rojas in order that I may have whatever corrections, and
amplifications that you can give me. I would appreciate it greatly if you would
read this, answer certain special questions about certain paragraphs and then call
in a public stenographer or secretary and dictate to her whatever answers and other
details you can give me. I shall be only too glad to pay the expense. I do not
wish to anticipate or to detract from your own story. Do you plan to publish
yours as a book or merely submit it to a journal? I think, however, our stories
are quite different in scope and purpose. I understand yours will be a collection
of personal recollections. Mine, of course, is a collection of data published, and
unpublished, covering the work of all those concerned. May I particularly ask your
help in answering the following questions, in order that we may have the Cuban
government memorialize the right site of Camp Lazear. My second special request is
that you permit me to quote you and of course give you full credit for whatever data
you can give me as to the true nature of Lazear's illness. I am sure that General
Kean, and I believe also Miss Agramonte are now willing for this data to be mentioned,
in order that, on the most appropriate occasion, on the dedication of a Lazear
Memorial, we could give Lazear some long withheld credit. May I now ask you certain
specific questions, pertaining to the paragraphs in my memorandum.
ok

Paragraph 6: Do you know when the tent Camp Columbia was Jan. 1894
erected, what the site was used for before that when the tent Camp Columbia was
replaced by the wooden Columbia Barracks July 1899 and when the latter was replaced by the
present Military City? Do you recall the relationship of the railroad track to
Camp Columbia or Columbia Barracks? See other side this sheet.

It was
entirely
vacant
land

Paragraph 11: Do you know the exact date during the first week
in August that Reed left Havana for Washington? Aug 2d 1900. I sailed with
him on this Transport “Rawlins” but returned to Columbia Bks before Reed died.

Par. 12: Between Aug. 11 and 25, 1900, Lazear applied infected
mosquitos to nine U.S. soldiers, which included Lazear, Carroll and Pinto. The other
six remain unidentified. Do you have any idea who they were? No., Enlisted men I think
Case no. 3 May have been Lazear but the age given is 24. Lazear was 34.

Par. 13: Kissinger's version of the inoculation of Dean is as
follows: Dean, having scoffed at the yellow fever work, had the habit of napping after
lunch in the hospital where he was a patient. On the morning that Carroll's illness
was diagnosed as experimental yellow fever, Lazear wanted a volunteer at once. Accord-
ing to Kissinger, Lazear found Dean asleep, and put the mosquito on him while he was
asleep. Later, when Dean heard how he had gotten yellow fever, presumably he was angry
at first, later enjoyed being a hero. This version differs entirely with Agramonte's
version (see Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1915). Did you ever hear anything to support
Kissinger's version?

There were
all sorts of
rumors re-
this and
Kissingers
may have
heard this
(see other)
(side)

Agramonte's version can, I am sure, be disprove
T
Our yellow fever ward was across the R.R. tracks
near where you located it. There was no tree or
even any chrubbery in 1900. There is quite a
deep cut at that spot where the tracks are
and it was difficult for us to get over there
so a bridge was constructed by the C.M. Dept.
about the time Kissinger was taken there for
treatment from Camp Lazear. Dr. Lazear died there
Moran was treated there.

I think it was approximately 200 yds due west from
our medical Officer's quarters (Reed lived with us) to the
tents of the yellow fever ward- It was a busy
place during the Quemados epidemic, earlier in 1900-

I feel certain that Lazear obtained Dean's
consent to be bitten. Lazear did this all by
himself and Agramonte was not present.
I am sure that this can be definitely proven, if
desired-

Paragraph 14: Did Lazear and Carroll have a formal pact no not to
be inoculated and was this authorized by Reed? No- Where Agramonte did Carroll do his convalescing?
Was it in the post hospital at Columbia Barracks? yes-

Par. 15-16: Anything on the real story of Lazear's illness you have it that I
can quote, I shall be most grateful for, and I am delighted with whatever you have sent
me. Do I have the authority to quote you on the occasion of my address at Washington
and Jefferson College? yes

(See other side) Par. 16: Did Dr. Lazear die in the post hospital at Columbia Barracks?
Where was he buried, when and where was the body re-interred, and where does he now lie?

Par. 17: Do you have any information on the correspondence between
Reed in Washington and Carroll or Agramonte in Havana regarding Lazear's death. No.
I think Kean probably did all the writing & cabling. Both Kean & I wrote to
Mrs. Lazear.

Par. 19: Reed left Havana “about the middle of October, 1900” to
go to Washington and Indianapolis. Do you know the exact date?- Oct 14th

Par. 21: Reed returned to Havana “early in November, 1900”. Do
you know the date? Nov 4th or 5th. I am not sure which is right.

(See other side) Par. 22: Do you know what the exact personnel of Camp Lazear was?
The official records do not make clear who were the eleven soldiers who went into resi-
dence at Camp Lazear on November 20, 1900. In particular, I am anxious to have any
information on the following points: Do you personally know anything about the circum-
stances of the volunteer of Moran and Kissinger? Did they go to Reed together (as Moran
says) or separately (as Kissinger says). How was the call for volunteers put out?
by Reed? by Dr. Ames? and in what form, in written notice or by word of mouth?

Par. 23: What was the exact method used for inoculating Kissinger,
Moran, Benigno, and Presedo between Nov. 20 and 30, 1900? Where, at Camp Lazear, did the
inoculations take place, in Reed's office tent or in the volunteers' own tents? Who
officiated and carried out the actual inoculation? Did Reed always do this? When was
the building of the Infected Clothing Building begun? It was first occupied Nov. 30, 1900.
When was Building No. 2 begun? It was occupied Dec. 21. Who were the two volunteers who
slept in the Infected Mosquito Building between Dec. 21 and Jan. 8.

Par. 29: Do you know anything about the disbanding of Camp Lazear? no
Did you personally ever visit the Camp? yes. Could you see any hilly country near the Camp? Bathing
Do you remember the relation of the camp to the Rojas farm house, its distance and
direction? no.
Par. 49: I want your reaction to this. See your mms- par 49
Par. 101-104: Please give me your reaction to these. See mms.

See other side Par. 111-112: You remember that Reed spoke of the appearance of
yellow fever at #120 Real Street and #20 General Lee St. I believe some American officers
or soldiers were quartered there. Do you know who they were?

Par. 115-116: I am especially anxious for you to check these
paragraphs. See mms.
Par. 118: May I have your opinion of this? See mms.
Par. 127: Please comment on this. No par. 127.
Par 120 is the last one on the mms.

Ac
T

Par 16 Lazear died in the tent y. f. ward on
(your false site of Camp Lazear) the west side of the
railroad tracks I think perhaps it was a little
further north of the tree shown in your photos. He
was buried in our military cemetery a few hundred
yards from our hospital down the old road to La Playa- His remains
were removed later to the London cemetery in Balto, Md.

Par 22 They were mostly from the group which later
volunteered but I have no exact list-
Kissinger went first, and entirely independent
of Moran. Moran is mistakened in his statement,
but he volunteered almost immediately afterwards.
There was no call for volunteers. It was entirely
by word of mouth. The Officers & Enlisted men all know
of Reed's work and that the Spanish volunteers
were an uncertain group. When Kissinger
& Moran volunteered the rest followed promptly-

23. Reed did it all himself at the Camp (Lazear) but
I was never present at such times. Carroll
attended to the infection of mosquitos on cases
at Las Animas. He no doubt assisted Reed
in some cases, but Carroll was still convalescing
from her attack of y.f. Most cases of y.f. recovered very
promptly but Carroll was an exception. It took
him several months to get back to normal
Buildings 1 & 2 were both begun & finished at
the same time-

Par. 111-112 20 General Lee St occupied by a
civilian Q.M. packer Henry S King & his wife. These were
probably the two first cases of yellow fever in Quemados. (May 19th)
Cases developed at 102 Real st. June 3.d 4th & 8th, I do not know
their names. Maj Edmunds lived at no 17 General Lee st. Heand
his wife became sick on 26th & 28th, respectively
General Kean lived near the Edmunds. on the same st.

Is Dr. Ames living? no Reed's letter to Carroll Feb. 26, 1900,
says Ames had a map of the Quemados epidemic. I wish indeed I could trace this
map. Have you written Mrs Ames. Kean, I think, has her address.

I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your wonderful help.
Your last letter was extremely interesting, and I certainly do appreciate it.
Permit me to send you a copy of a questionnaire I sent to Gen. Kean. If you can
give me any of the answers, I will certainly appreciate it. You may wish to
have the secretary or stenographer who helps answer this letter make an extra
carbon for yourself. Please ask her to send me an extra carbon also. If you
do not mind, I know General Kean will be most anxious to see it.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Keep the photos of your work. If you can tell me any
data about then you can simply refer to the number I've
given each one. Do you want the photostat of your
letter from Reed or may I keep it. I'd love to.

I will keep some of the photos. Thanks-
AET
